awd_titl_txt: Research: Invisible Gendered Experiences in Engineering Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Existing research shows that a student's experience in higher education is shaped by one's gender. This has been shown to be particularly true in engineering, where some students face additional barriers to their success based on their gender. This project will investigate gender through collaborative, community-engaged research methodologies. In particular, researchers will work with undergraduate engineering students to document engineering-specific experiences. Researchers will prioritize collaboration; together with the students, they will identify strategies which foster positive educational outcomes and share these with engineering departments, faculty and administrators towards the end of advancing the success of students in engineering programs.

The research project has three objectives: (i) to infuse critical theory and methodologies into engineering education research; (ii) to record, examine, and share how undergraduate engineering students of different genders find belonging and success; and (iii) to collaborate with research participants to generate recommendations toward transforming engineering programs into more inclusive and just spaces. Analysis will inform understandings of resiliency in the face of gender marginalization as well as potential subjugation linked to other intersecting identities. 

This project integrates critical collaborative ethnography and research justice methodologies, which centralize the principle of the research population being the foremost experts on their own experiences. Power is shifted to the subject community through involving them in knowledge production, analysis, and distribution. Three phases of research include an outreach questionnaire to identify participants and emerging themes, personal interviews, and on-site collaborative ethnographic observation. The initial outreach questionnaire will be distributed nationally through campus cultural groups and other campus communities, peer-to-peer communication, and through engineering departments. A subset (n=20) of the respondents who indicate an interest in further collaboration will be invited to participate in phenomenological interviews that will explore students' experiences of gender in engineering, and experiences with supportive structures that provoke resiliency. Five of these students will then be invited to participate in a five-day site visit. During this period, the student will collaboratively engage with the researchers in ethnographic observation of the student's campus community and support network. In addition, an online community which prioritizes confidentiality and identity protection will be created and all students who completed the initial questionnaire will be invited to join. Here, the student community and the researchers will work together to analyze data, to document community-identified sources of success and perseverance, and to develop recommendations of effective practices, policies and norms that contribute to inclusive, equitable and just learning environments. This project is of significant intellectual importance because it provides a broader contemporary framing of gender and how these identities affect the professional formation of engineers, an area that has received very little attention to-date.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Engineering as a field is dominated by toxic masculinity, heteronormativity, whiteness, and cisnormativity. There is a significant lack of research focused on the experiences of transgender and gender nonconforming (TGNC) students in engineering and most existing studies do not consider the complex intersections of marginalized identities that can impact a student’s sense of belonging. This study addresses these research gaps and highlights students’ sources of resiliency in the face of unique barriers.

 

Methodologies

The research team consisted of scholars in women, gender, and sexuality studies, bioengineering, and engineering education. The interdisciplinary nature of our team is a significant strength, allowing in-depth analyses of the lived experiences of TGNC engineering students by using critical theories to enhance the understanding of the participants’ social and educational environments. A central aspect of our methodological approach was the examination of spatiality and intersectionality. Analyses of place and space are crucial when studying transgender experiences, as identity expression and concealment are directly linked to the ability to express marginalized identities without ostracization.

 

An intentional feature of our method called for two transgender and queer researchers to be the only points of contact with the student participants. These two researchers bonded with the participants because of their shared transgender identity and were welcomed into the participants’ social networks as community members rather than seen as outsiders. Participants were positioned to co-create results, empowering them to maintain agency in their interactions with the researchers and exert control over their portrayal. Another study feature that bolstered participants’ agency was the Virtual Research Community, implemented through a Slack platform. This space allowed for broad TGNC student input over the course of the study and provided a supportive space for participants to engage with one another. 

 

Outreach questionnaire

The outreach questionnaire contained 17 Likert-scale items and 7 open-text prompts. Respondents (n=299; 33.7% racial/ethnic minoritized status and about 40% non-binary/gender nonconforming) provided information regarding their perceptions of their skills, success strategies, community support, and personal suggestions for improving TGNC undergraduate engineering experience.

 

Mean responses and associated standard deviations to all Likert-scale items are presented in Figure 1. An important feature of this data is the relatively large standard deviation associated with each item, highlighting the diversity of experiences and perceptions within the TGNC engineering student population. Significant relationships were noted across gender, disability status, and geographic region.

 

Phenomenological interviews

The interview participants (n=21) were intentionally selected to prevent the overrepresentation of dominant identities (i.e. white, nondisabled), and to ensure adequate gender and geographic region representation. The participants were emailed the conversation protocol which contained roughly one-half “required” questions, with the remaining being “opt-in” points of conversation. Participants were allowed to select “opt-in” questions and choose the duration of the conversation (between 60 and 120 minutes). The results were interpreted thematically: defining the complex self, sources of support, navigating communities, online spaces, and suggestions for enhancing inclusion within engineering education. The data provide an intimate look into TGNC students’ perspectives and outlooks, revealing that most participants expressed doubts regarding the supportiveness of engineering culture. Participants formed caring communities outside of engineering contexts which bolstered their success. Online spaces and political involvement were persistent themes.

 

Collaborative ethnographic site visits

Six undergraduate, TGNC engineering or computer science majors (20% racial/ethnic minoritized status and 50% non-binary/gender nonconforming) participated in this portion of the study, representing four different geographical regions of the U.S. (Pacific West; Mountain West; West North Central; New England). The visiting researcher conducted semi-structured interviews and engaged in informal interactions with the participants, including attending classes, hanging out with friends, attending local events, sharing meals, and exploring the campus and the broader community. The site visit data revealed that identity construction was closely tied to the safety of the participants’ geographic area, considering factors like anti-trans legislation prevalence and the local social climate (conservatism vs. progressivism). Attending predominately white institutions intensified feelings of alienation for BIPOC participants. Additionally, while non-binary participants faced identity erasure through incorrect pronoun usage or denial of their non-binary identity, binary transgender participants faced the most overt discrimination and violence, institutionally, socially, and administratively. Participants found support outside engineering in culturally specific communities.

 

Implications and suggestions for engineering education

Across all three stages of the project, participants recommended strategies for bolstering belonging and success for engineers who exist beyond the presumed cisgender experience such as integrating social justice education into engineering curricula and incorporating inclusive practices into classrooms. Many participants highlighted that a general cultural change is needed and expressed hope for continuing research in TGNC engineering student experience.

 

The research team calls for a paradigm shift away from depoliticization in engineering culture and STEM more broadly and for prioritizing faculty development opportunities that explicitly focus on LGBTQIA+ and racial equity. Because engineering culture embeds racial and LGBTQIA+ bias, curricula must address social justice issues to counter it.
